chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Renunciation of Action
sanskrit:
विद्याविनयसम्पन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि ।
शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः ॥१८॥
transliteration:
vidyā-vinaya-sampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini |
śuni caiva śvapāke ca paṇḍitāḥ sama-darśinaḥ ||18||
translation: The truly wise, endowed with knowledge and humility, see with equal vision a learned and humble Brahmin, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even an outcaste dog-eater.
commentary:
This verse presents one of the most revolutionary teachings of the Bhagavad Gita regarding spiritual equality and the vision of the enlightened. Krishna describes how those who have attained true wisdom (paṇḍitāḥ) perceive all beings with equal vision (sama-darśinaḥ). The examples given span the entire spectrum of the social hierarchy of ancient India—from the most respected (a learned Brahmin) to the most despised (a dog-eater or outcaste), and from large animals to small ones. This equal vision is not based on external characteristics, social status, or physical form, but on the recognition of the same divine essence, the Atman, dwelling within all beings.

This teaching directly relates to the chapter's theme of karma-sannyasa (renunciation of action) because such equal vision can only arise when one has transcended ego-identification and the dualities created by the mind. The truly wise person sees beyond the temporary material body and perceives the eternal spiritual essence in all creatures. This verse establishes the foundation for genuine spiritual practice—one cannot claim to be a yogi or a person of knowledge while harboring prejudices based on birth, species, or social status. The combination of vidyā (knowledge) and vinaya (humility) is emphasized as essential for this realization, indicating that mere intellectual understanding without the accompanying virtue of humility cannot produce this equal vision.
speaker: Krishna
